ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I think that this course sis well at teaching me the introductory basics of chemistry.
I learned how to do basic chemistry
General chem knowledge.
general introduction to chemistry
Critical thinking / studying skills
Basic Chemistry principles and theories
Learned about chemistry basics.
Basic understanding of fundamental principles of chemistry  ionic compounds, orbitals, solubility rules, etc.
I learned a lot about the molecules that make up the universe and how they arrange themselves in our lives.
I learnt very much from this course. It was well structured and gave me a great grasp of the chemistry knowledge needed to access university level chemistry
basic chem knowledge
A foundational knowledge of general chemistry including the basics of molecular chemistry, thermodynamics, solution chemistry and stoichiometry.
Not too many. Just learned some more in depth stuff about chemistry than I learned in AP chem.
Knowledge on understanding chemical formulas and structures

CHEM 161 has pretty standard content for general chemistry: basic atom interactions, stoichiometry and balancing equations, solubility and acid-base reactions, redox reactions, gas laws, thermochemistry, molecular geometry and orbitals, intermolecular forces, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that this course was done really well. The lectures were presented nicely and the homework was straightforward. I always felt as if the subject matter was relevant.
I thought it was taught well but the tests were hard
The discussion sections could have been more organized, and more time could be put into lecture for breaking down the problems and complex topics we were diving into.
lectures were helpful and achieve assignments helped reinforce material. the exams seemed more difficult than concepts covered in class
I thought it was taught very well. Paul does a really good job explaining all the concepts
Strength: the course covers a lot of important introductory knowledge. Weakness: the course covers A LOT of
The course was a pretty standard lecture course with homework, I honestly wouldn't change a thing.

Extremely well organized  a rarity, it seems, at this school, especially in STEM courses  and very clear teaching and expectations. It was pretty simple to figure out what might be on the exam, and Prof. Cooper was extremely kind presented material clearly and efficiently. I honestly wouldn't change anything about this course  it was exactly what a gen chem course should be, and there were no surprises.
The lectures were efficient and fun. However, the sections lacked engagement and efficiency.
Perhaps more practice questions could be given to students.

It was very difficult to follow when the exams were entirely different from the materials we had gone over in class. The final exam had problems we had never encountered how to do but wanted you to apply concepts to figure it out even though it was not something we covered in class. It was difficult to study too because the tests were all so different from the class. Frustrating situation for a student whos never taken chemistry and is studying what we did in class only to be blind sided by an exam.

strengths: goes over core chemistry 
weaknesses: hard

Professor Cooper is a wonderful lecturer although I don't think understanding the course content is dependent upon attending lecture. The assignments were very conducive to developing understanding and the format of them online through Achieve I enjoyed very much. I also think that the discussion section outlines were very helpful to guiding discussion sections and future studying.
The achieve is good for helping learn the material. I think section was a huge weakness. I did not learn a single thing during section and stopped going after the third week.

Strengths: Professor Cooper was clear in his lectures and accessible for questions. There were many ways (adaptive quizzes, section review, homework, pre-section quizzes, etc.) to learn content.
Weaknesses: Online homework was relatively easy to answer without much thought by using a few of the allotted attempts, which made it possible to go without truly absorbing content until directly studying for tests, and this became overwhelming. Section was not organized to make students work together on the assignments, and it felt relatively easy to slip through the cracks on learning content if you were busy with other classes. Content is quite hard if you have not had a strong background in chemistry and tests cover content in new ways that are hard to conceptualize if you have not seen the information before.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! While the course is necessary for many majors, I also think that it's a great class and can be pretty fun. If you like chemistry at all, I think it's worth a try.
if you have to take it sure, but I don't like chemistry
if you need to take this as a prereq then yes
Only if they are interested in chemistry
Probably not. The course is a prerequisite and is organized like it.
I would, you get the chem basics in a good way.
Yep, great intro chem course. Low-stress, relatively speaking, but I still learned a lot.
Yes, it will help you understand many future concepts in STEM classes.
Yes. If you've had a year or two of chemistry in high school this class should be fairly easy. Also, Prof. Cooper is a great lecturer -- he presents content very clearly and efficiently.
Yes, i will recommend this to anyone whos interested in learning chemistry in a structured way
I would not reccomend it unless you need it for the reasons stated above.
only with prof Cooper. AND GO TO HIS OFFICE HOURS IF YOU DON'T UNDERSTAND
Yes, although students are probably only going to take this course as a pre-requisite. I don't know if I'd recommend it outside of that.

Only if you have to take it. I guess some of the topics are interesting to learn about if you are curious about the chemistry of life. It is not super hard either so definitely doable for a non-stem person, but some topics can be hard.

CHEM 161 is tough, particularly if you haven't had a background in chemistry, and it takes personal dedication to make sure you're truly absorbing content each week and not leaving everything until you need to study for tests. Professor Cooper is accessible and open, and explains content pretty clearly, but the amount of information to learn and the speed of lectures can make it hard to absorb. The content, which is largely based around equations and rules but also delves into the conceptual basis for these generalities, is pretty interesting, which helps with the workload. Each midterm tested content in ways that felt relatively unfamiliar and each homework took several hours, in addition to other assignments for the class.
